case_study.title: Case Study: The Classic Car
case_study.scenario: Ahmed restores a vintage car that he co-owns with his sister, Fatima. They both contribute to its upkeep. Ahmed takes out an insurance policy in his name only for the full market value of the car. A month later, before Fatima has been added to the policy, the car is stolen from a locked garage. The insurer questions whether Ahmed can claim for the full value of the car.

questions.question: Does Ahmed have insurable interest in the car, and if so, to what extent?
questions.answer: Yes, Ahmed has insurable interest as a part-owner. Legally, he can insure the property for its full value because, as a co-owner, he is considered a trustee for his sister's share. He has a legal right to insure arising out of a financial relationship with the car.

questions.question: When did insurable interest need to exist for Ahmed's policy to be valid?
questions.answer: For general insurance, such as a motor policy, insurable interest must exist at the time the policy is taken out and, crucially, at the time of the loss. Since Ahmed was still a co-owner when the car was stolen, the requirement is met.

questions.question: Why can't you take out a fire insurance policy on your neighbor's house?
questions.explanation: No financial loss would fall on you if the house burned.

questions.question: For which class of insurance must insurable interest exist only at the time the policy is taken out (at inception)?
questions.explanation: The timing requirement for insurable interest varies. For life insurance, it must exist at inception. For general insurance, it must exist at inception and at the time of loss. For marine insurance, it must exist at the time of loss.

questions.question: A dry cleaner holding a customer's suit has an insurable interest in it because they are a ________.
questions.explanation: A bailee (someone temporarily holding property) would suffer loss if the goods were damaged in their care.

questions.question: Insurable interest can arise from:
questions.explanation: These are the recognised sources of insurable interest.

questions.question: In insurance, ‘insurable interest’ most closely means:
options: The financial relationship a person has with the subject insured
The interest paid on premium instalments
questions.correctAnswer: The financial relationship a person has with the subject insured
questions.explanation: It must be a legally recognised financial stake in the subject-matter.

questions.question: For a private motor policy to be enforceable at law, insurable interest must exist at least:
options: At the time of any claim
questions.correctAnswer: At the time of any claim
questions.explanation: As a type of general insurance, a motor policy requires insurable interest to exist at the time of the loss. It is also required at the time the policy is taken out.

questions.question: Sam borrows a friend’s car and asks for a comprehensive policy in Sam’s own name on that car alone. The broker refuses because Sam lacks:
questions.explanation: Sam has no legal/financial relationship to that car.

questions.concept: Case Law - Macaura v. Northern Assurance Co. (1925)
questions.question: Mr. Macaura owned a timber estate and sold the timber to a company he formed, of which he was the sole shareholder. He insured the timber in his own name. When the timber was destroyed by fire, his claim was denied. Why?
options: He, as a shareholder, did not have a separate insurable interest in the company's assets.
The fire was found to be deliberate.
The timber was undervalued on the policy.
questions.correctAnswer: He, as a shareholder, did not have a separate insurable interest in the company's assets.
questions.explanation: The case of Macaura v. Northern Assurance Co. (1925) established that the property of a company belongs to the company, not its shareholders. A shareholder's interest is in the company itself (the shares), not directly in its physical assets.

flashcards.definition: Legally recognised financial relationship with the subject-matter of insurance.
The thing or interest insured (property, liability, life, etc.).
Holder of another’s property who owes a duty of care; has insurable interest.

Varies by class: General Insurance requires it at inception AND at time of loss. Life Insurance requires it only at inception. Marine Insurance requires it at time of loss (but not necessarily inception).
Landmark case establishing that a shareholder does not have a direct insurable interest in the assets of the company, even if they are the sole shareholder. The company is a separate legal entity.
